page.title: 12LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: The area has been under the sea six times. Glaciation halted at the top of Nashleigh Hill. Palaeoithic tools found. Before Conquest part of Cestreham (now Chesham) first recorded 1227 as Essleie, Anglo-Saxon word meaning Ash Woods. Trees were felled for taxes and clearing formed for pigs to graze - recorded in Feudal Aids 1468 as Assheley Grene. Green not common land - 'manorial waste'. Three ley lines cross spot marked for centuries by a pudding stone, moved when chucrch built, now on green near horse chestnut tree marking depth of well - 185ft. well to tree. Church built by Elizabeth Dorrien of Bristol in memory of her sisters; designed by George Street, cosecrated in 1873, now listed building. Mary Anne Smith-Dorrien of Haresfoot built scho- ol in 1850 offering education to all.
